title: 113_hr4777
content: The "Health Savings Act of 2014" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for health savings accounts for children. The "Health Savings Act of 2014" allows for child health savings accounts, where individuals can deduct cash contributions made to an account for their child or grandchild. The deduction is limited to a certain amount per child each year. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows for child health savings accounts with monthly limitations on contributions for eligible individuals. The aggregate amount of contributions to all child health savings accounts cannot exceed the monthly limitations for each month the child is eligible. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows for child health savings accounts with monthly contribution limits. A child health savings account established for a taxpayer's child is treated as the taxpayer's account until no deduction is allowable for the child, after which it becomes the child's account. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows for child health savings accounts with monthly contribution limits. Qualified medical expenses for the child's account do not include amounts paid for medical care for anyone other than the child. Exceptions apply if the child becomes disabled or dies, allowing rollover of funds to another health savings account. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows for child health savings accounts with monthly contribution limits. Legal guardians are treated as parents for the child's account. Regulations will be prescribed for application in various scenarios. Amounts in the account will not affect means-tested programs. Amendments apply to taxable years after enactment. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows for child health savings accounts with monthly contribution limits. Legal guardians are treated as parents for the child's account. Regulations will be prescribed for application in various scenarios. Amounts in the account will not affect means-tested programs. Amendments apply to taxable years after enactment. SEC. 3. ALLOWING HSA ROLLOVER TO CHILD OR PARENT OF ACCOUNT HOLDER. The Health Savings Act of 2014 allows child, parent, or grandparent beneficiaries for health savings accounts. Amendments include allowing a child to have a health savings account treated as a child health savings account. Effective date for these changes is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 increases the maximum contribution limit to Health Savings Accounts (HSA) to the amount of deductible and out-of-pocket limitation for both self-only and family coverage. SEC. 5 allows for the transfer of required minimum distribution from a retirement plan to a Health Savings Account. Transfer From Retirement Plan: Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer required minimum distributions to a Health Savings Account, excluding it from gross income. This allows for qualified HSA transfers from individual retirement plans. Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer distributions from an individual retirement plan to a health savings account in a direct trustee-to-trustee transfer. The distribution cannot exceed the required minimum distribution for the year. The amount distributed from the retirement plan is included in gross income to the extent required. Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer distributions from an individual retirement plan to a health savings account, with the amount included in gross income not exceeding the aggregate amount that would have been included if all amounts from all retirement plans were distributed. Proper adjustments are made for other distributions in the taxable year and subsequent years. An election under this provision cannot be made if an election is already in effect under another paragraph. Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer distributions from a retirement plan to a health savings account, with the amount not exceeding the required minimum distribution for the year. Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer distributions from a retirement plan to a health savings account, with the amount not exceeding the required minimum distribution for the year. In determining the extent of gross income inclusion from an individual retirement plan, the aggregate amount distributed is considered, subject to adjustments in subsequent taxable years. The term 'eligible retirement plan' is defined as per subsection (c)(8)(B). Individuals aged 70 1/2 can transfer distributions from a retirement plan to a health savings account, with the amount not exceeding the required minimum distribution for the year. The amendments allow for qualified HSA transfers described in section 408(d)(10) or 402(m) without incurring excise tax. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6 amends Section 522 of title 11, United States Code, to treat health savings accounts like individual retirement accounts. The effective date is after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7 allows silver and bronze plans with health savings accounts. Section 223 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace "high deductible health plan" with "HSA compatible health plan" in various subsections. The term "HSA compatible health plan" is defined as part of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace "high deductible health plan" with "HSA compatible health plan" in various subsections, including plans enrolled in through an Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Clerical amendments are made to update the headings accordingly. The amendments replace "high deductible health plan" with "HSA compatible health plan" in specific subsection headings, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. SEC. 8 amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to require identification of HSA compatible plans starting in 2015.
